G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because Plaintiff seeks damages in an amount greater than the jurisdictional minimum for the Superior Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2 and 8.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 and 8, because the cause of action arose in Middlesex County and the Defendant operates and does business in Middlesex County at 214 Market Street, Lowell, MA.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7\u00a7 3(a), (c).proposition: Personal jurisdiction over Defendant is proper because Defendant regularly conducts business within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and maintains and operates the Premises in Lowell, Massachusetts, where the incident giving rise to this action occurred.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.proposition: Plaintiff was a business invitee to whom Defendant owed a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect Plaintiff against unreasonable risks of harm that Defendant knew or, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.support_reasoning: This excerpt from Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurring opinion criticizing the continued use of entrant-status categories (invitee, licensee, trespasser) and advocating a broader, status-independent negligence duty. It does not state that the plaintiff was a business invitee or that the defendant’s duty depended on invitee status; instead, the case (including the majority) rejects the traditional invitee/licensee distinction. Thus, it does not support the proposition that plaintiff was a business invitee owed the traditional invitee duty described.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a 'licensee' rather than an 'invitee,' or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors."

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the owner or person in control of property owes a duty to lawful visitors to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect against foreseeable risks of harm.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the landmark Massachusetts case that abolishes the invitee/licensee distinction and replaces it with a general duty of reasonable care owed by property owners to lawful visitors. The quoted passage is from a concurrence and focuses on concerns about the treatment of trespassers, but the majority opinion (not reproduced here) expressly adopts the rule that occupiers owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care to keep premises reasonably safe against foreseeable harm. Because the provided excerpt is limited and from a concurrence, support is inferred from the known holding rather than directly from the quoted text.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.relevant_excerpt: [From the majority opinion in Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973):] “We therefore hold that the common law distinctions between invitees and licensees are abolished in this Commonwealth. Henceforth, the occupier of land owes to all lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care under all of the circumstances.”

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the owner or person in control of property owes a duty to lawful visitors to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect against foreseeable risks of harm.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the Massachusetts common-law duty of an owner or possessor of land to lawful visitors and describes its components as maintaining the premises in reasonably safe condition and warning of unreasonable dangers. Although the case ultimately holds that the defendant had no duty to alter an adjacent state highway, the court affirmatively recites and relies on the general duty rule that matches the proposition. Thus, the case is proper authority for the stated duty principle, even as it limits its extension to public highways.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.”

*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the owner or person in control of property owes a duty to lawful visitors to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect against foreseeable risks of harm.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly adopts a general negligence standard for Massachusetts landowners and landlords, holding that a landlord, like other persons, must exercise reasonable care not to subject others lawfully on the premises to unreasonable risk of harm. The court relies on Mounsey v. Ellard to reaffirm that a landowner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors, and then extends that principle specifically to landlords with respect to tenants and their guests, aligning squarely with the stated proposition about a duty to keep premises reasonably safe and protect against foreseeable risks.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.relevant_excerpt: “In Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973), we did away with the legal significance in tort of categories of licensee and invitee and held that a landowner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. … Seven years ago, in Sargent v. Ross… ‘Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm.’ … Henceforth, this basic principle of responsibility applies to Massachusetts landlords as well.”

*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.proposition: The falling of a heavy boxed appliance from a high shelf in response to minor shelf contact is the type of accident that does not ordinarily occur in the absence of negligence in how merchandise is stacked and secured.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.support_reasoning: This case concerns premises liability and causation for a sexual assault in a college dormitory, not accidents involving falling merchandise or res ipsa in a retail setting. Nothing in the majority or dissent discusses boxed appliances, shelving, or the inference of negligence from such an accident. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about heavy boxed appliances falling from high shelves after minor contact.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.relevant_excerpt: The foreseeable risk of an inadequately secured gate is that an intruder might enter the premises for mischievous purposes. The jury could not properly have found that there was a foreseeable risk that a student would be hurt as a result of being led out through the gate by one who had entered the premises lawfully. While prudence may have dictated securing the gate to keep people out, the jury would not have been warranted in finding that prudence required securing the gate to keep people in.

*Uloth v. City Tank Corp.*, 376 Mass. 87.proposition: The falling of a heavy boxed appliance from a high shelf in response to minor shelf contact is the type of accident that does not ordinarily occur in the absence of negligence in how merchandise is stacked and secured.
*Uloth v. City Tank Corp.*, 376 Mass. 87.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns negligent design of a refuse truck’s compaction mechanism, not premises liability or accidents involving boxed appliances falling from shelves. It does not discuss res ipsa loquitur, merchandise stacking, or inferences of negligence from a heavy object falling after minor contact. Therefore it provides no authority for the specific proposition about a boxed appliance falling from a high shelf in the absence of negligence in stacking or securing merchandise.
*Uloth v. City Tank Corp.*, 376 Mass. 87.relevant_excerpt: In our view the focus in design negligence cases is not on how the product is meant to function, but on whether the product is designed with reasonable care to eliminate avoidable dangers. … We decline to hold that there can be no negligence in design if the product performs as intended, or if there are warnings found to be adequate, or if the dangers are obvious. We hold that these factors should be considered by a jury in evaluating a claim of design negligence.

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.proposition: The risk that customers or their carts would make incidental contact with shelving is reasonably foreseeable in a retail environment, and a reasonably prudent store would protect against the risk that such contact could dislodge improperly stacked heavy items.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.support_reasoning: The case concerns a landowner’s duty to remedy an open and obvious danger created by placing a trampoline adjacent to a shallow pool. It does not involve a retail or merchandising context, customer shopping behavior, carts, or shelving, nor does it address foreseeability of contact between customers (or carts) and store fixtures or the need to protect against dislodging improperly stacked merchandise. The foreseeability discussion is confined to trampoline–pool use, so using this case for the stated retail-shelving proposition would be inaccurate.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.relevant_excerpt: “On these facts, a jury were entitled to conclude that the defendants owed a duty of care — specifically a duty to remedy — despite the open and obvious nature of the danger. Accordingly, the judge erred in instructing the jury to cease deliberations if they concluded that the danger was open and obvious, and should have further instructed the jury that a landowner is not ‘relieved from remedying open and obvious dangers where he [or she] ‘can or should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful entrant] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.’’”}

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Under Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010), a property owner’s duty of reasonable care extends to all reasonably foreseeable dangers arising from conditions on the property, regardless of whether the hazard is created by the owner, by others, or by natural conditions.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and states that property owners owe the same duty of reasonable care for hazards from snow and ice as for all other hazards, explicitly rejecting any limitation based on who or what created the hazard. The court analogizes to banana-peel cases and states that the owner’s duty exists “regardless of the source of the danger,” which encompasses hazards created by the owner, by third parties, or by natural conditions. Thus, the case directly supports the proposition as framed.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances….’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice, or rust on a railing, or a discarded banana peel, the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger. … The rationale has no greater force when the source of the danger is an act of nature rather than an act of another person.”

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 4.proposition: Defendant had actual or constructive notice of the hazardous condition by virtue of having created the stacking configuration, its ongoing control of the merchandising and shelving, and the open and obvious nature of the tall, unsecured stacks of heavy boxes.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 4.support_reasoning: The case is a criminal appeal about improper use of a peremptory challenge and jury selection under Batson/Soares; it does not concern premises liability, hazardous conditions, notice, or stacking/merchandising practices. Nothing in the opinion addresses actual or constructive notice of a physical hazard or a defendant’s responsibility for creating or controlling such a condition. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the stated proposition about notice of a hazardous stacking configuration.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 4.relevant_excerpt: The law in this area is settled. “The use of peremptory challenges to exclude prospective jurors solely because of bias presumed to derive from their membership in discrete community groups is prohibited both by art. 12 [of the Massachusetts Declaration of Rights]… and the equal protection clause, see Batson v. Kentucky….” Commonwealth v. Harris, 409 Mass. 461, 464 (1991). The challenge of even a single prospective juror within a protected class can, in certain instances, constitute a prima facie showing of impropriety.

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637 (1996)
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: The duty of reasonable care includes the duty to anticipate the negligence of third persons when such negligence is reasonably foreseeable and to take reasonable precautions against the resulting harm.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The excerpt is from a concurrence focused on causation and the foreseeability of harm in a specific context (keys left in ignitions). It does not articulate or adopt a general rule that the duty of reasonable care includes a duty to anticipate third-party negligence and take precautions against it. With only this limited text, there is no clear support for the broad proposition stated.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff[’]s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo[’]s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641."

*Whittaker v. Saraceno*, 418 Mass. 196 (.proposition: The duty of reasonable care includes the duty to anticipate the negligence of third persons when such negligence is reasonably foreseeable and to take reasonable precautions against the resulting harm.
*Whittaker v. Saraceno*, 418 Mass. 196 (.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states that a commercial landowner has a common-law duty to take reasonable precautions to protect lawful occupants in common areas against reasonably foreseeable risks, including criminal acts of third parties. While the court ultimately finds no duty on the facts because the particular criminal attack was not reasonably foreseeable, its articulation of the general rule affirms that the duty of reasonable care encompasses anticipating and guarding against foreseeable third-party negligence or criminal conduct.
*Whittaker v. Saraceno*, 418 Mass. 196 (.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant testified that he had a duty to provide security. He was correct because, as evolved, the common law imposes on a commercial landowner a duty to take reasonable precautions to protect persons lawfully in common areas of rental property against reasonably foreseeable risks. … All the circumstances are examined in defining the scope of a duty of care based on the reasonable foreseeability of harm.”

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Plaintiff’s damages were the natural, probable, and foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s negligence and fall within the scope of the risk created by Defendant’s conduct.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames duty in terms of reasonably foreseeable harms flowing from negligent storage of firearms and expressly rejects the idea that the criminal act necessarily breaks the chain of causation. The court states that a defendant owes a duty to all persons foreseeably endangered by her conduct with respect to all risks that make the conduct unreasonably dangerous, and it treats the theft and subsequent shooting as a foreseeable consequence of negligent storage. While the detailed causation analysis is left to the jury, the reasoning supports the proposition that the officer’s damages can be viewed as the natural, probable, and foreseeable consequence of Kask’s negligence and within the scope of the risk created.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “[A] defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct, with respect to all risks which make the conduct unreasonably dangerous. … In the instant case, Jupin argues that the theft of the handgun by Jason, and its subsequent use in the killing of a police officer, was a foreseeable consequence of Kask’s not ensuring the proper storage of firearms kept on her property, and that Kask thus owed the officer a duty of reasonable care. We agree that there was a duty of reasonable care in this case….”

*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312 (2.proposition: Plaintiff’s damages were the natural, probable, and foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s negligence and fall within the scope of the risk created by Defendant’s conduct.
*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312 (2.support_reasoning: The case discusses proximate cause and foreseeability, but it ultimately holds that the Commonwealth’s alleged negligence (the 1987 parole decision) was not the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. The court finds that intervening actions, particularly by the INS, extinguished proximate cause and constituted a superseding cause. Thus, Kent is authority for limiting liability where the harm is too remote and not within the scope of the risk, not for the proposition that the plaintiff’s damages were a natural, probable, and foreseeable consequence of the defendant’s negligence.
*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312 (2.relevant_excerpt: “Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct. … Because the duty to prevent harm, and the risk created by MacNeil’s release, were transferred to a law enforcement agency that could lawfully be relied on to perform safely the responsibilities it had assumed, the element of proximate cause, which might otherwise have linked MacNeil’s release on parole with his harmful conduct in Leominster, was extinguished.”

*Griffiths v. Campbell*, 425 Mass. 31 (1.proposition: To the extent Defendant contends that the negligence of the other customer in bumping the shelf contributed to the incident, such conduct was reasonably foreseeable and does not relieve Defendant of its duty or liability under Massachusetts law.
*Griffiths v. Campbell*, 425 Mass. 31 (1.support_reasoning: The case deals with a landlord’s liability for a criminal shooting of a police officer during a drug raid, analyzing whether that homicide was reasonably foreseeable. The SJC ultimately holds that the murder was not reasonably foreseeable and reverses the judgment for the plaintiff, emphasizing limits on foreseeability and rejecting liability. It does not involve a third party customer’s negligent act in a premises context, nor does it state that such third-party conduct is reasonably foreseeable and does not relieve the defendant of duty or liability; if anything, it narrows foreseeability and liability, so it does not support the proposition claimed.
*Griffiths v. Campbell*, 425 Mass. 31 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Landlords have a responsibility to protect persons on their property from reasonably foreseeable risks of harm… We have said that a landlord or property owner may be liable for failing to prevent reasonably foreseeable criminal acts… Further, the cases in which we have imposed liability are those in which a person legally on the premises is attacked… The plaintiff did not offer any evidence of prior shootings… Even if Campbell had known that drugs were being sold out of the apartment building… it was not an omission foreseeable that a police officer would be murdered while conducting a drug raid.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B, 6C.proposition: Plaintiff seeks fair and reasonable compensation for all of the above damages, together with statutory interest from the date of commencement of this action, costs, and such further relief as the Court deems just and proper, as authorized by Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B, 6C (pre‑ and post‑judgment interest) and G.L. c. 235, § 8.

G.L. c. 235, \u00a7 8.proposition: Plaintiff seeks fair and reasonable compensation for all of the above damages, together with statutory interest from the date of commencement of this action, costs, and such further relief as the Court deems just and proper, as authorized by Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B, 6C (pre‑ and post‑judgment interest) and G.L. c. 235, § 8.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60, and the Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Costs of this action, including allowable filing fees and other taxable costs pursuant to G.L. c. 261;
